title: Spring loaded dart and two blocks

content.question:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

The figure above shows a dart and blocks, which move through labeled regions <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>a</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> through <math alttext="e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>e</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. In region <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>a</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the dart of mass <math alttext="m equals, 0.050 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.050</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is pushed against an ideal spring, compressing the spring a distance <math alttext="x equals 0.20 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.20</mn><mtext> m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The dart is released from rest. The spring has a spring constant <math alttext="k equals, 25 newtons per meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn><mtext> N/m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Calculate the speed of the dart immediately after it is launched.

In region <math alttext="b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>b</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the dart strikes block 1 of mass <math alttext="m sub 1 equals, 0.250 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.250</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and becomes embedded in the block.

frqParts.text:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

The figure above shows a dart and blocks, which move through labeled regions <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>a</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> through <math alttext="e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>e</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. In region <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>a</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the dart of mass <math alttext="m equals, 0.050 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.050</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is pushed against an ideal spring, compressing the spring a distance <math alttext="x equals 0.20 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.20</mn><mtext> m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The dart is released from rest. The spring has a spring constant <math alttext="k equals, 25 newtons per meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn><mtext> N/m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Calculate the speed of the dart immediately after it is launched.

In region <math alttext="b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>b</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the dart strikes block 1 of mass <math alttext="m sub 1 equals, 0.250 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.250</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and becomes embedded in the block.

(b) Calculate the speed of the dart-block system immediately after the collision.
The dart-block system slides a short distance across the table. In region <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>c</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the dart-block system enters a rough region of length <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in which the coefficient of kinetic friction between block 1 and the surface decreases linearly as the block moves through the region.

(c) On the axes below, sketch the speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and magnitude of the acceleration <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of block 1 as functions of distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as the block moves through the rough region.

(d) The dart-block system exits the rough region traveling at <math alttext="0.25 meter per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.25</mn><mtext> m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, enters region <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>d</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and collides head-on with block 2 of mass <math alttext="m sub 2 equals, 0.450 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.450</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is at rest near the edge of the table. After the collision, the dart-block system rebounds to the left with speed <math alttext="0.050 meter per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.050</mn><mtext> m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
i. Calculate the speed of the second block immediately after the collision.

ii. Is the collision elastic?

_____ Yes _____ No

Justify your answer. 

(e) In region <math alttext="e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>e</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, block 2 leaves the table while traveling horizontally to the right. The surface of the table is a height <math alttext="y equals 0.75 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.75</mn><mtext> m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> above the floor.
i. Calculate the distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the base of the table to where block 2 lands on the floor.

ii. If the table had twice the height, would the time between leaving the table and reaching the floor for block 2 increase, decrease, or stay the same?
_____ Increase _____ Decrease _____ Stay the same
Justify your answer.

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
